briefing.headline: The Missing Ocean Equipment Case
briefing.narrativeHtml:
Learning Targets for Today:

  • I can use maps to locate coral reefs and tropical islands
  • I can research ocean animals and their underwater homes
  • I can explain how islands are different from continents
  • I can understand why people need to protect coral reefs
  • I can identify Pacific Ocean countries on a world map

Your Mission: Help Sourdough Pete track down Dr. Coral! She's been taking underwater research equipment because she's worried about coral reefs getting damaged. She thinks she's helping the ocean, but taking things that don't belong to you is wrong! Follow the clues using your maps, globes, and research skills to find her underwater hideout.

What You'll Need: World map, globe, atlas with ocean maps, and internet for research about coral reefs and sea animals

Ocean Detective Challenge: Dr. Coral loves swimming underwater and studying colorful coral reefs. Can you follow her trail through 5 ocean clues?

suspects.name: Dr. Coral (Maya Sari)
suspects.description: A scientist who loves swimming underwater and studying colorful coral reefs. She cares so much about protecting ocean animals that she makes bad choices like taking equipment that doesn't belong to her.

rounds.clueHtml:
Ocean Detective Clue #1:

Dr. Coral was spotted swimming near beautiful tropical islands! Here's what we know:

  • She's in a place where the water is warm, clear, and bright blue
  • There are palm trees growing on small islands surrounded by ocean
  • The water is so clear you can see colorful fish and coral on the bottom
  • These islands are scattered across the biggest ocean in the world

Your job: Use your world map to find the biggest ocean and look for tropical islands with coral reefs!
researchPrompts: Look on your world map for the biggest ocean
Find tropical islands with palm trees in warm, clear water
Research where coral reefs grow in the ocean
Look up the Pacific Ocean and its tropical islands
expectedProcess: Student identifies Pacific Ocean as the largest ocean
Student locates tropical islands on Pacific Ocean maps
Student learns about coral reefs in warm, shallow water
Student connects tropical climate to coral growth
rounds.explainHtml:
Great ocean detective work! You found the tropical Pacific islands!

The Pacific Ocean is the biggest ocean in the world, and it has thousands of small tropical islands with warm, clear water. These islands have coral reefs - underwater gardens made of tiny animals that build colorful, rocky homes for fish.

What You Learned:

  • The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean on Earth
  • Tropical islands have warm water, palm trees, and coral reefs
  • Coral reefs are like underwater cities where many sea animals live
  • Clear, warm water is perfect for coral reefs to grow

rounds.clueHtml:
Ocean Detective Clue #2:

Dr. Coral is now swimming underwater with the fish! Here's what our underwater cameras spotted:

  • She's swimming with a snorkel and mask in shallow, warm water
  • There are lots of colorful tropical fish swimming around her - yellow, blue, and striped ones!
  • She's also swimming near big sea turtles that eat sea grass and algae
  • The water is so clear she can see all the way to the coral reef on the bottom

Your job: Research the biggest coral reef in the world where lots of colorful fish and sea turtles live!
researchPrompts: Look up the biggest coral reef in the world
Research colorful tropical fish that live in coral reefs
Find information about sea turtles and where they live
Look up the Great Barrier Reef in Australia
expectedProcess: Student researches the Great Barrier Reef
Student learns about tropical fish species
Student discovers sea turtles live in coral reefs
Student understands coral reefs support many animals

reveal.note: Expert at underwater swimming and fish watching

rounds.explainHtml:
Amazing underwater detective work! You found the Great Barrier Reef!

The Great Barrier Reef in Australia is the biggest coral reef in the world! It's so big you can see it from space! Thousands of different colorful fish live there, along with sea turtles, dolphins, and even sharks. The coral reef is like an underwater city where all these sea animals have their homes.

What You Learned:

  • The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest coral reef system
  • Coral reefs are home to many different kinds of tropical fish
  • Sea turtles live in coral reefs and eat sea plants
  • Australia is a continent surrounded by ocean with amazing coral reefs

rounds.clueHtml:
Ocean Detective Clue #3:

Dr. Coral is now using a research boat to travel between islands! Here's what we spotted:

  • She's on a white boat with 'OCEAN RESEARCH' written on the side
  • The boat is traveling between small island countries in the warm part of the Pacific Ocean
  • These islands are home to people who have lived on islands for thousands of years
  • The boat is near an area that has the most different kinds of coral and fish in the whole world!

Your job: Find the area in the Pacific Ocean that has the most coral reefs and sea life of anywhere on Earth!
researchPrompts: Look up the Coral Triangle in the Pacific Ocean
Research which area has the most coral reef species
Find island countries in Southeast Asia
Look up Indonesia, Philippines, and Malaysia on your map
expectedProcess: Student researches the Coral Triangle region
Student learns about marine biodiversity hotspots
Student locates Southeast Asian island nations
Student understands coral reef diversity

reveal.note: Expert at island hopping and ocean navigation

rounds.explainHtml:
Fantastic island detective work! You found the Coral Triangle!

The Coral Triangle is an area in the Pacific Ocean between Indonesia, the Philippines, and Malaysia. It's called the 'Amazon of the Ocean' because it has more different kinds of coral, fish, and sea creatures than anywhere else in the world! The people who live on these islands have been fishing and taking care of the ocean for thousands of years.

What You Learned:

  • The Coral Triangle has the most marine life diversity on Earth
  • Island countries like Indonesia and the Philippines are made of many small islands
  • People can live on islands and travel between them by boat
  • Different parts of the ocean have different amounts of sea life

rounds.clueHtml:
Ocean Detective Clue #4:

Dr. Coral is now at a place where people go to learn about ocean animals! Here's what we found:

  • She's in a big building with huge tanks full of sea water and live coral
  • There are signs everywhere that say 'SAVE THE OCEAN' and 'PROTECT CORAL REEFS'
  • Kids and families come here to see real sea turtles, sharks, and tropical fish up close
  • This place teaches people why coral reefs are important and how to protect them

Your job: Find a place where people go to see ocean animals and learn about protecting coral reefs!
researchPrompts: Look up marine aquariums and ocean education centers
Research places where people can see live coral reefs indoors
Find aquariums that teach about ocean conservation
Look up famous aquariums in Australia or coastal cities
expectedProcess: Student researches marine aquariums and education centers
Student learns about ocean conservation education
Student understands how aquariums help protect sea life
Student connects education to conservation

reveal.trait: Teaches people about protecting the ocean
reveal.note: Expert at showing others why coral reefs matter

rounds.explainHtml:
Excellent ocean education detective work! You found a marine education center!

Marine aquariums and education centers are special places where people can see live coral reefs, sea turtles, and tropical fish without going underwater. They teach kids and families why coral reefs are so important - they're like underwater nurseries where baby fish grow up, and they protect islands from big ocean waves.

What You Learned:

  • Aquariums help people learn about ocean animals without disturbing them in the wild
  • Coral reefs need protection because they're homes for many sea creatures
  • Education helps people understand why we need to take care of the ocean
  • Scientists work to protect coral reefs and teach others about them

rounds.clueHtml:
FINAL Ocean Detective Clue:

We found Dr. Coral's secret plan! She's working with island families to protect coral reefs. Here's her final hideout:

  • She's on a beautiful Pacific island teaching local kids about coral reefs
  • The island people have been taking care of their coral reefs for hundreds of years
  • She's showing them pictures from her underwater camera of sick and healthy coral
  • She wants island families to know that their coral reefs need extra help right now

Final Mission: You've followed Dr. Coral through her whole ocean adventure! Find where she's teaching island communities about protecting their coral reefs!
researchPrompts: Think about all the Pacific islands you've learned about
Research how island people take care of coral reefs
Look up why coral reefs are important to island communities
Consider where Dr. Coral would want to teach kids about ocean protection
expectedProcess: Student reviews all previous ocean and island clues
Student learns about community-based reef protection
Student understands Dr. Coral's educational mission
Student identifies Pacific island communities

reveal.trait: WANTS TO TEACH KIDS ABOUT PROTECTING CORAL REEFS
reveal.note: Her real goal: Help island families take better care of their underwater gardens!

rounds.explainHtml:
CASE SOLVED! You caught Dr. Coral at her ocean education center!

Dr. Coral wasn't really trying to be bad - she just loves coral reefs so much that she made some wrong choices. She was taking equipment because she wanted to teach island families that their beautiful coral reefs are getting sick from pollution and warm water. Coral reefs are like underwater gardens that need special care to stay healthy.

What You Accomplished:

  • You learned to use maps to find oceans, islands, and coral reefs
  • You discovered amazing ocean animals like tropical fish and sea turtles
  • You researched how people live on islands and take care of the ocean
  • You understand why coral reefs are important underwater homes for sea life

Sourdough Pete says: 'Fantastic ocean detective work! You learned that caring about sea animals and coral reefs is wonderful, but there are right ways and wrong ways to help. Dr. Coral should have asked permission instead of taking equipment that didn't belong to her!'

solution.item: Underwater cameras and coral research equipment

suspect.name: Dr. Coral (Maya Sari)
suspect.notes: Ocean swimmer, coral reef lover, underwater explorer, ocean education teacher

resolution.summaryHtml:
What Students Learned About Oceans:

  • Pacific Ocean: Biggest ocean in the world, tropical islands, warm clear water
  • Coral Reefs: Underwater homes for fish, colorful living gardens, need protection
  • Sea Animals: Tropical fish, sea turtles, sharks, dolphins in coral reef homes
  • Island Countries: Places like Australia, Indonesia, Philippines made of islands
  • Ocean Protection: Why coral reefs matter, how pollution hurts sea life
  • Island Communities: People who live on islands and take care of coral reefs
  • Geography Skills: Using maps to find oceans, islands, and coral reef locations

Why This Case Works for 11-Year-Olds:

Age-Appropriate Content: Ocean animals, swimming, islands, protecting sea life

Map Skills: Pacific Ocean, tropical islands, country identification, reef locations

Educational Progression: Tropical islands → underwater animals → island travel → ocean education → community protection

Real Learning: Geography, ocean science, conservation, and caring for our planet!
learningExtensions: Learn more about coral reefs and the fish that live there
Research how people can help protect coral reefs
Find coral reefs on a world map and learn about different types
Study sea turtles and their ocean habitats
Learn about Pacific island countries and their cultures
Explore how islands are different from continents
Research marine aquariums and ocean education centers near you
Learn about careers helping ocean animals and coral reefs
crossCurricular: Geography: Pacific Ocean, tropical islands, Australia, Southeast Asia
Science: Coral reefs, ocean animals, marine habitats, conservation
Environmental Studies: Protecting coral reefs, ocean pollution, conservation
Social Studies: Island communities, Pacific island cultures, ocean resources
Math: Ocean depths, distances between islands, counting coral species
Reading: Ocean animal books, coral reef stories, conservation articles
Art: Drawing tropical fish, coral reef scenes, ocean conservation posters
